the city of aiken south carolina source materials used in the preparation of the the 1980 as supplemented ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1980 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 code index cdi1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the of this  effect of repeal of ordinances the repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect the repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect nor any suit prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed  general penalty for violations of ordinances  continuing violations a whenever in this any other ordinance any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or whenever in this any other ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful where no specific penalty is provided therefor the person violating any such provision of this other ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $50000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 30 days or both each day any violation of any provision of this of any ordinance continues shall constitute a separate offense unless otherwise provided b in addition any person found guilty of violating any provision of this be ordered to pay restitution in an amount not to exceed $500000 in determining the amount of restitution the judge shall determine and itemize the actual amount of damage or loss in the order in addition the judge may set an appropriate payment schedule a municipal judge may hold a party in contempt for failure to pay the restitution ordered if the judge finds the party has the ability to pay c where there is any conflict between the maximum penalty provided by the statutory law of the state and this any other ordinance of the city for the same or similar offenses the maximum punishment provided by the state statute shall govern d in addition to the penalties provided for in subsections a and b of this section any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this be deemed a public nuisance and may be by the city abated as provided by law and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense  114 state law reference authority of council to fix fines and penalties for violation of ordinances sc   trial of persons charged with ordinance violations sc   maximum penalty that municipal courts may impose sc  police jurisdiction over parking lots a the procedure for bringing parking lots not owned or leased by the city under public safety department jurisdiction of the city shall be as follows the owner of a parking lot in the city which is open to use by the public for motor vehicle traffic shall petition the director of public safety requesting that the city exercise police jurisdiction over such parking lot the director of public safety should determine that such petition is signed by or on behalf of the owners or owner of a majority of the area of such parking lot and should ascertain the number of signs to be posted to inform the public that the area is subject to the police jurisdiction of the city the petitioners shall pay the city for the number of signs determined by the director of public safety to be necessary at a rate specified by the director b upon the requirements of subsection a of this section being met the director of public safety should request that the parking lot in question be posted with appropriate signs informing the public that the area is subject to the police jurisdiction of the city with regard to the unlawful operation of motor vehicles and violations of applicable city ordinances c upon an owner or owners filing a request or petition to put a parking lot under public safety jurisdiction referred to in subsection a jurisdiction of the city and the city acting department of public safety shall thereupon have the authority to enforce in such parking lot all laws and ordinances relating to the unlawful operation of motor vehicles applicable to the public streets and highways immediately adjoining or connecting to the parking area as well as all other applicable ordinances of the city and laws and statutes of the state    exh a 2232004 administration footnotes  1  cross federal or state law  secs 25230  reserved article ii  city council division 1  generally composition the mayor and six council members shall be termed the council and shall be the governing body of the city  state law reference composition of council in cities with councilmanager form of government sc  oath of office before entering upon the duties of their offices the mayor and members of the council shall take the oath of office prescribed by sc  other officers of the city and such members of commissions and committees as may be designated by the council shall take the following oath to be administered by the city clerk i do solemnly swear or affirm that i am duly qualified according to the constitution of this state to exercise the duties of the office to which i have been elected or appointed  that as name of office of the city of aiken i will equally fairly and impartially to the best of my ability and skill exercise the trust reposed in me and i will use my best endeavors to preserve the peace and to carry into effect according to law the purposes for which i have been elected or appointed and will preserve protect and defend the constitution of this state and the united states so help me god  qualifications of council members the mayor and council members shall be qualified electors of the city and shall hold no other public office or public employment with the city county or state except that of notary public appointed school board member or a member of the national guard or other federal military reserve if a council member or the mayor shall cease to possess any of these qualifications or shall be convicted of malfeasance in office or a crime involving moral turpitude his office shall immediately become vacant  state law reference mayor and council member to be qualified electors of city sc  filling of vacancies vacancies in the office of mayor or council member shall be filled by special election if the vacancy occurs more than 180 days prior to the next city general election for the unexpired portion of the term if the vacancy occurs less than 180 days before a city general election the vacancy shall be filled at the general election for the unexpired term as provided by law  state law reference similar provisions sc  election schedule a the following dates and times are hereby established for nomination and election of candidates for regularly scheduled municipal general elections to council including the mayor that are conducted in oddnumbered years 1 the opening of filing for nomination petitions and other filing of candidates for nomination in municipal political party primaries or conventions shall be  noon on the first monday in july 2 the closing of the filing of candidates for nomination by political parties shall be  noon on the second monday of july 3 closing of entries for nomination by petition shall be  noon on the 75th day prior to the municipal general election 4 municipal party primaries or conventions shall be conducted on the second tuesday in august 5 municipal party primary runoffs if necessary shall be conducted on the fourth tuesday in august 6 last day for certifying candidates to the municipal election commission shall be  noon on the 60th day prior to the municipal general election 7 the municipal general election for council members and mayor shall be conducted on the first tuesday after the first monday in november b in the event of a vacancy on council requiring a special election council shall follow the election schedule for special elections in sc as amended or any program they must be participants in the city employees retirement plan who retire on or after attaining age 55 with at least 12 years of service 1 an eligible council member who retires with at least 12 years of service with the city but is less than age 55 may continue his coverage under the citys health insurance program at his own cost until attaining age 55 at age 60 the city will offset any monthly pension check which may be payable to a former member of the council by the monthly premium for health insurance payable by the former member the remaining portion of the pension check shall be directly deposited by the city 2 all eligible council members who retire on or after age 55 may elect to continue their health insurance coverage and the cost of continued coverage shall be divided between the city and the retiree as follows retirement at or after age 55 with years of service percentage of cost paid by city less than 12 0 12 28 15 40 20 60 25 80 an additional four percent is added for each full year of service after 12 years up to 25 years of service example for 12 years of service the city will pay 28 percent of the cost of health insurance coverage in no event will the city pay more than 80 percent of the monthly insurance premium 3 the city reserves the right to change or modify its health insurance program from time to time and continue coverage as is available under the health insurance program as modified from time to time 4 a former council members election to continue coverage under the citys health insurance program must be made at the time of the members retirement when the member is first eligible to elect continued health insurance coverage if the member fails to elect to continue coverage under the citys health insurance program at the time the member is first eligible the former member may not later elect to participate also if the former member elects to participate in the citys health insurance program after retirement and later stops participating or the coverage ceases due to the members failure to pay the required premiums the member shall not be allowed to rejoin or reelect health insurance coverage under the citys program 5 determination of salary of mayor and council members sc  general powers all legislative powers of the city and the determination of all matters of policy shall be vested in the council without limitation of the foregoing the council shall have power to 1 adopt the budget of the city 2 authorize the issuance of bonds by a bond ordinance subject to such restrictions and limitations as may be prescribed by law 3 inquire into and investigate the conduct of any city office department or agency and make investigations as to municipal affairs 4 adopt plats 5 adopt the official map of the city and modify the official map from time to time as the need may require 6 regulate and restrict the height and number of stories of buildings and other structures the size of yards and courts the density of population of land and the location and use of buildings for trade industry business residence or other purposes 7 provide for safe and sanitary housing accommodations for families of low income 8 create a housing authority 9 adopt modify and carry out plans proposed by the planning commission for the clearance of slum districts and rehabilitation of blighted areas 10 adopt modify and carry out plans proposed by the planning commission for the replanning improvement and development of neighborhoods and for the replanning reconstruction or redevelopment of any area or district which may have been destroyed in whole or in part by disaster 11 provide for an annual independent audit by a qualified certified public accountant designated by the council such certified public accountant shall as of the end of each fiscal year make an independent audit of the accounts and other evidence of financial transactions of the city government for the immediate past year and shall submit this report to the council and to the city manager the designated accountant shall have no personal interest direct or indirect in the fiscal affairs of the city government or of any of its officers but within specifications approved by the council shall postaudit the books and documents kept by any office department board agency or commission of the city government  state law reference similar provisions sc  51330 52310 powers with respect to offices boards commission etc a the council by ordinance may create change and abolish offices departments boards agencies and commissions b the council may appoint and remove all members of the municipal boards agencies and commissions established by the council state law or constitution except as otherwise provided by state law such boards and commissions shall serve as advisory bodies to the council and shall not exercise administrative responsibility except as may be otherwise provided by law terms of the board agency or commission members shall be as provided by ordinance state law or constitution  general functions of mayor the mayor shall be recognized as head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law and shall execute all official documents of the city but shall have no regular administrative duties  emergency powers of mayor a for the purposes of this section a state of emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever during times of great public crisis disaster rioting civil disturbance catastrophe or for any other reason municipal public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives safety health welfare or property b in the event of a state of emergency threatening or endangering the lives safety health and welfare of the people within the city or threatening damage to or destruction of property the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of such a state of emergency and in order more effectively to protect the lives safety and property of people within the city to define and impose a curfew applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the city c the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to limit the application of such a curfew to any area specifically designated and described within the jurisdiction of the city and to specific hours of the day or night  and to exempt from the curfew public safety officers doctors nurses and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve the safety health and welfare needs of the people within the city d the city council shall be called into session within 24 hours after a state of emergency has been proclaimed by the mayor e the mayor shall proclaim the end of such state of emergency and curfew as soon as circumstances warrant or when directed to do so by the city council f during the existence of proclaimed state of emergency when a curfew has been defined and imposed it shall be unlawful for anyone subject to such curfew 1 to be or travel upon any public street alley or roadway or upon public property unless such travel is necessary to obtain medical assistance 2 to possess off ones own premises buy sell give away or otherwise transfer or dispose of any explosives firearms ammunition or dangerous weapon of any kind 3 to sell beer wines or intoxicating beverages of any kind  or to possess or consume beer wines or intoxicating beverages of any kind off ones own premises 4 to sell gasoline or any other similar petroleum products or any combustible or inflammable substances except as expressly authorized by the provisions of the curfew imposed  mayor pro tempore the council shall elect one of its members as mayor pro tempore to serve as such for two years who shall act as mayor during the absence or disability of the mayor and if a vacancy occurs shall become mayor until a successor is duly qualified and elected  state law reference similar provisions sc  limitations on dealing with administrative service neither the council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to or his removal from office by the city manager or by any of his subordinates or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of officers and employees in the administrative service of the city except for the purposes of inquiry and investigation the council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely city manager and neither the council nor any member thereof shall give orders to any subordinates of the city manager either publicly or privately any council members violating the provisions of this section or voting for a resolution or ordinance in violation of this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office and shall thereby disqualify himself as a member of the council  secs 243260  reserved division 2 unless changed by a majority vote of members present at any regular or special meeting b special meetings of the council may be held on the call of the mayor or of a majority of the members notice of a special meeting shall be given immediately to all available members and the news media by the city manager c all regular and special meetings of the council shall be open to the public d for annexations rezonings and utility requests before aiken city council affecting a particular piece of real estate such matter shall also be given public notice by posting a public notice sign at least 20 days prior to the first scheduled public hearing before city council on the subject property and in a location clearly visible from each street adjacent to the particular piece of property this public notice sign shall be in substantially the same form as the public notice sign utilized by the planning department for matters pending before the historic preservation commission board of zoning conference meetings as permitted by the state freedom of information act at such times and in such places as may be deemed necessary and in the public interest by the mayor or any member of the council no formal vote shall be taken upon any matter under discussion at any such conference but an informal polling of the council may be made if desired by any member of the council b the city manager may if time permits give notice to the local news media or anyone requesting in writing advance notice that a conference meeting will be held pursuant to law without stating the specific matters to be discussed when advance notice is not given the city manager may give notice of such meeting after it has been held c no vote of the council shall be necessary to call a conference meeting  quorum  presiding officer  rules of order a majority of the members of the council serving shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business at any meeting the mayor or mayor pro tempore shall preside except that in the absence of both the members shall elect a presiding member except as otherwise required by state law or this all proceedings of the council shall be governed by roberts rules of order newly revised  rules of order a rules of procedure 1 authority sc  provides that the council shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall provide for keeping minutes of its proceedings which shall be a public record 2 purpose the purpose of city council in adopting rules of order is to enable the council to transact business with speed and efficiency while protecting the rights of all persons whether in the majority or the minority arbitrary technical rules must not prevent the council from accomplishing the publics business therefore it is the intent of the council that common sense and courtesy be applied when enforcing the rules of procedure so that the will of the majority of the council may be achieved while insuring that all positions are heard and considered 3 presiding officer normally the mayor or in the mayors absence the mayor pro tempore shall preside at any meeting notwithstanding that however city council may upon motion passed by a twothirds majority of all council members serving elect a council chairperson and vicechairperson who shall then serve as presiding officer at all future meetings until the next general or special election at which any member of the council including the mayor is elected and takes office in the event that the mayor or mayor pro tempore or chairperson or vicechairperson is not in attendance or is ineligible to preside at any meeting the members present shall elect a member to preside 4 order of business the standard order of business which shall be reflected in the meeting agenda shall be as follows a call to order b invocation c pledge of allegiance d approval or correction of agenda  e approval or correction of minutes f public requests presentation of petitions awards memorials g nonagenda items from the public total time limited to 30 minutes and each speaker limited to three minutes h second reading and adoption of ordinances i first reading and advertisement of ordinances j resolutions k motions l nonagenda items from the public each speaker limited to three minutes m communications from the city council and the city manager n reports and information presentations from city staff o executive session  p adjournment 5 procedure pursuant to the agenda a information and presentation items many items on a meeting agenda do not involve a decision making or legislative action on the part of the council these include the invocation presentations awards and nonagenda items from the public when these items are reached on the agenda the presiding officer should simply announce them and introduce the individual or group who will be making the presentation or providing the information if a discussion involving the presenters and council members is appropriate the presiding officer should control the discussion to maintain proper decorum and to insure that the discussion remains relevant to the agenda topic when it becomes apparent that the subject has been thoroughly covered or the discussion has become redundant or strayed from the topic the presiding officer should with the consensus of the council end the discussion and announce the next agenda item b legislative items the council takes action by resolution or ordinance ordinances must be in writing and in the form required for final adoption when introduced resolutions are most commonly introduced in writing but may be introduced and approved in oral form upon reaching an ordinance or resolution on the agenda the presiding officer will read the ordinance or resolution by title or the presiding officer may ask the city clerk to read it and ask the city manager to present a brief explanation of the ordinance to include its expected effect and who has proposed it the manager may ask a staff member or a retained expert to give this briefing after the managers briefing the presiding officer will call for a motion from the council if no motion is made or if the motion is not seconded the presiding officer will move on to the next agenda item if a motion is made and seconded the presiding officer will call for discussion in the following order 1 the applicant or its representative council members may ask questions of the applicant or its representative during the applicants presentation 2 individuals to address council  any citizen resident or other interested individual may address council during the first or second reading of an ordinance or resolution the presiding officer may alternate between proponents and opponents when recognizing individuals to address council council members may ask questions of the individual during the individuals presentation 3 the mayor and members of council during the presentation of each member of council and the mayor they may also ask questions of any speaker who will be asked to return to the podium to respond to the questions after the discussion is completed the presiding officer shall if the motion has not been disposed of or postponed by subsidiary motion immediately restate the motion before council and call for the vote of council following the vote the presiding officer should immediately announce the results c nonagenda items nonagenda items from the public or staff will be accepted only for the information of the council 6 motions a motion is the means by which the city council takes any legislative action motions are ranked in order of precedence a motion may be made only if no motion of equal or higher precedence is on the floor the precedence of each motion is indicated in brackets after its title all motions must be seconded and are adopted by majority vote unless otherwise noted all motions may be debated unless otherwise noted these motions indicated by an asterisk may be made at any time that they are relevant to the issue presently on the floor or the decision which has just been made a motion to adjourn  not debatable  goes to immediate majority vote b call for the orders of the day  directs the presiding officer to return to the approved agenda not debatable c call the question  not debatable closes debate on the motion on the floor and forces a vote on that motion requires a twothirdsmajority vote d motion to limit or extend limits of debate  not debatable can be amended requires a twothirdsmajority vote e motion to refer  should specify which committee board or commission the matter is to be referred to what council expects the group to do and when it should be reported back to council approval of this motion ends discussion of the matter and the presiding officer should proceed to the next agenda item f motion to continue  may be made instead of a main motion when an agenda item comes before the council or at any time before the main motion is disposed of should specify when the matter is to be brought back before the council and what action or information is desired before it is brought back if approved it ends consideration of the agenda item for the current meeting and the presiding officer should move to the next item g motion to amend  h main motion  i motion to appeal decision of the presiding officer  not debatable requires immediate vote always stated by presiding officer so that a yes vote sustains his or her decision presiding officer retains the chair but must proceed as voted by the majority j object to the consideration of a question once agenda is approved requires twothirdsmajority vote not debatable k point of order this is a request from a member for action by the presiding officer and may be made even when someone else has been recognized to speak no second is required  no amendment is permitted  and no vote is required unless the presiding officer asks the council to decide the issue or the decision of the presiding officer is appealed the point of order is frequently used to question a procedure undertaken by the presiding officer or to suggest an alternate procedure to the presiding officer l motion to reconsider may only be made before adjournment of the meeting at which the original action was taken must be made by a council member who voted on the winning side on the original action nothing in this subsection should be construed to prevent the original matter from being placed on the agenda for a subsequent meeting if requested by at least three council members after 90 days the original matter may be added to a meeting agenda using the same procedure as with any other matter not previously decided by council m motion to suspend the rules can be made at any time that no question is pending if a matter is before the council and the motion to suspend is applicable to that matter the motion to suspend takes precedence over all other motions it is not debatable or amendable and requires a twothirdsmajority to pass this motion permits the council to do something it wishes to do but cannot without violating one or more of the rules contained in its rules of procedure this motion cannot be used to modify or suspend any requirement of state law 7 public hearings a public hearing is a special type of meeting it is intended to provide the council the opportunity to gather information from public input and provide information to the public state law requires that a public hearing be conducted under certain circumstances the presiding officer should call the hearing to order and announce the purpose of the hearing the presiding officer should recognize individuals who wish to address council and should ensure that representatives of all competing views have a fair opportunity to express those views the council can take no action during the public hearing a public hearing may be a separate meeting or may be held during a regular council meeting if it is during a regular council meeting it generally occurs at the point on the agenda where the subject of the public hearing is listed for action in that case the presiding officer must clearly announce the start of the hearing and the adjournment of the hearing so that it is clear when the special rules applicable to the hearing apply and when the rules of procedure for regular council business are restored a record of each public hearing must be kept and should include a a hearing agenda b a record of all the members of the public who participate c proof of any required notice or publication d minutes or a tape of the proceedings e copies of any materials received from the public or distributed to the public 8 disruptive conduct these rules of procedure are adopted based on the expectation that all persons attending a meeting of the city council will be honorable and will conduct themselves with courtesy for all other individuals present in most situations where an individuals conduct becomes disruptive it will be inadvertent and a warning from the presiding officer will be sufficient to correct the offensive behavior if that is not the case or if the presiding officer is determined by council to be disrupting or obstructing the proceedings of a council meeting the following shall apply a it is unlawful for any person to disrupt a meeting of city council if a person who is determined by the presiding officer or by a majority vote of council to be disruptive refuses to discontinue the disruptive behavior the matter will be immediately reported to the police department who will upon responding take necessary action to end the disruption action by the police may include if necessary removing the offending individual from the meeting room b in a case where the disruptive person is a member of council a determination that the disruptive behavior is in violation of these rules shall be made by a majority vote of council c if the presiding officer refuses to call for action on a matter on an approved agenda ignores a motion apparently made and seconded in good faith refuses to allow council to vote on an appeal from a decision or ruling of the presiding officer or in any other way refuses to conduct the meeting in accordance with these rules council may by majority vote declare the chair vacated any council member may move to vacate the chair based on the refusal of the presiding officer and upon receiving a second the member who made the motion may call for the immediate vote of council if the motion receives a majority vote the position of presiding officer shall be filled for the remainder of the meeting as provided in subsection b3 of this section as if the presiding officer were absent unless the original presiding officer is removed from the meeting as provided in subsection b8a of this section he shall be permitted to remain in the meeting and participate as any other council member 9 items not covered any matter or order of procedure not covered by these rules shall be referred to the presiding officer who shall decide the matter in conformity with the purpose of these rules the decision of the presiding officer may be reversed on appeal by a majority vote of council      2112008 state law reference council to determine its own rules and order of business sc b footnotes  3  editors note the south carolina freedom of information act requires that an agenda be advertised 24 hours before the scheduled meeting time it has been argued by some parties that this prevents the amendment of the agenda after the advertisement the better argument seems to be that when it is necessary in the public interest to add a matter to the agenda after it is published the council may do so  4  editors note when related to the item being considered an executive session may be held at the time a matter is being discussed if a majority of the council votes to do so  5  editors note there is no state ordinance  6  editors note these motions may be made at any time that they are relevant to the issue presently on the floor or the decision which has just been made agenda matters to be considered by 2112008 introduction of resolutions a voice motion of a member of the council shall be considered to be the introduction of an oral resolution which shall require no written record other than a notation of the city clerk in the council minutes a resolution proposed in writing shall be introduced in the same manner as an ordinance  enactment of ordinances a an ordinance to levy a tax adopt a passed and in such form remain on file with the city clerk for public inspection at least one week before final adoption b no ordinance shall be adopted until it shall have been read two times and on two separate days with at least six days between each reading c emergency ordinances may be adopted on one reading without notice or hearing by affirmative vote of twothirds of the members present an only unless a member of the council requests full reading however reading of an ordinance by title only shall be a sufficient reading upon both first and second readings as to any ordinance more than 500 words in length as to any ordinance adopting a technical code such as building zoning housing gas electric plumbing or other similar codes and as to adoption of sections of the laws of south carolina by reference provided that in regard to such ordinances reading in full may be required upon either first or second reading or both by majority vote of the council members present  e after the introduction of an ordinance whether on first reading or on second reading any member of the council or any citizen of the city or any other individual interested therein may request a public his department and subject to the city managers directives he shall furnish other departments such service labor and materials as may be necessary in accordance with such procedures and budgetary when required by the city manager c each department head shall perform such additional duties relating to the conduct of city affairs as may be assigned to him by the city manager or by law  state law determination of lowest responsible bidder a the purchasing agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this division  provided however that city council approval is required in the following instances 1 for contracts in excess of $2500000 for purchases not included specifically as budgeted items in the current budget  or 2 purchases which are not replacement items funded under the city depreciation accounts b contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in determining the lowest responsible bidder in addition to price the purchasing agent or city council shall consider 1 the ability capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required 2 whether the bidder can perform the contract provide the service promptly or do so within the time specified without delay or interference 3 the character integrity reputation judgment experience and efficiency of the bidder 4 the quality of performance of previous contracts or services 5 the previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or services 6 the sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service 7 the quality availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required 8 the ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract 9 the number and scope of conditions attached to the bid 10 whether the bidder has failed to fully perform prior contracts to the citys satisfaction or is past due delinquent or owes the city any money of any type   2119 3272000   exh a 1232006 local vendor preference in awarding bids a local vendor means a vendor who is considered to be a resident of the city or county if the vendor 1 is an individual partnership association or corporation that is authorized to transact business of the city or county  2 maintains an office in either the city or county  3 maintains an inventory for expendable items which are representative of the general type of commodities on which the bid is submitted and located in the city or county at the time of the bid having a total value of $1000000 or more based on the bid price but not to exceed the amount of the contract  and 4 has paid all assessed taxes fees costs or other revenue due to the city b no requirement contained in section 2338 shall preclude the award of bids to local vendors on the following basis 1 a bid from any vendor located within the city which is no more than five percent higher than the lowest bid received may be given preference under the terms of the city purchasing process provided that the difference between the two bids is not greater than $300000 2 a bid from any vendor located outside the municipal limits of the city but within the county which is not more than three percent higher than the lowest bid received from a vendor located outside the county may be given preference under the terms of the city purchasing process provided that the difference between the two bids is not greater than $300000 c competitive procurements made by the city shall be made from vendors resident in the city or county provided that the bidder has certified in writing in the bid that he or she is a resident of the city or county in order to receive the award the vendor must be a responsible and responsive bidder and the bid must otherwise comply with the the city in the case of a request for local vendor status this requirement shall apply to the entire solicitation d protest of any awarded bid is subject to these procedural requirements 1 right to protest  exclusive remedy any actual bidder offeror contractor or subcontractor who claims to be aggrieved in connection with the bid award shall protest to the purchasing agent in the manner stated in subsection 2 below within three business days of the date of award notification is given in accordance with this rights and remedies granted in this article to a disappointed bidder offeror contractor or subcontractor are to the exclusion of all other rights and remedies of disappointed bidders offerors contractors or subcontractors against the city at common law or otherwise for the loss or potential loss of an award of a contract under the city procurement code 2 protest procedure a protest under subsection 1 above shall be in writing submitted to the purchasing agent and shall set forth the grounds for the bid protest and the relief requested by them with enough particularity to give notice of the issues to be resolved 3 duty and authority to attempt to settle protests prior to commencement of an administrative review as provided in subsection 4 below the purchasing agent the head of the department or designees thereof shall attempt to settle by mutual agreement a protest by aggrieved bidders offerors contractors or subcontractors actual or prospective concerning the solicitation or award of the bid city department directors or their designees shall have the authority to approve any settlement reached by mutual agreement 4 administrative review and decision if in the opinion of the purchasing agent after reasonable attempt a protest cannot be settled by mutual agreement the purchasing agent shall promptly conduct an administrative review and shall issue a decision in writing within ten days of completion of this review the decision shall state the reasons for the action taken 5 notice of decision a copy of the decision under subsection 4 above shall be mailed or otherwise furnished immediately to the protestant and any other party intervening the purchasing agent shall also post a copy of the decision at a date and place communicated to all parties participating in the administrative review and such posted decision shall indicate the date of posting on its face 6 finality of decision a decision under subsection 4 above shall be final and conclusive unless fraudulent or unless any person adversely affected by the decision requests a further administrative review by the city manager within ten days of posting of the decision the request for review shall be directed to the purchasing agent who shall forward the request to the city manager and shall be in writing setting forth the reasons why the person disagrees with the decision of the purchasing agent e a bidder shall be suspended or debarred from doing business with the city if the city manager or designee determines that the certification made by the bidder as to the local vendor request was filed under false pretenses and is not valid in addition if the bidder with the invalid certification of origin was awarded the contract he shall also pay the city the amount by which the bid based on the invalid certification exceeded the lowest responsible and responsive bid that would have been selected but for the invalid certification plus reasonable attorney fees and costs if a bidder has not requested the reference he will neither be entitled to claim any preference against another bidder nor will he be protected from application of another bidders claim to a preference against his bid in determining contract award    exh a 1232006   exh a 3272006 award of contract in case of tie bids if all bids received are setoff debt collection procedures participation in setoff collection the city manager shall set the minimal amount for delinquent debts owed the city which it may submit to the state tax commission or any successor agency for collection pursuant to the setoff debt collection act or any successor provisions thereto in determining this amount the city manager shall consider the administrative and related costs of utilizing this collection procedure the amount of the potential recovery to the city and any other relevant factors  state law reference levy on and seizure of intangibles sc  procedures a the city shall notify a delinquent debtor of its intention to cause the debtors state tax refund to be setoff by notice given in person left at the dwelling or usual place of business of the debtor or sent by certified or registered mail to the debtors last known address no less than 30 days before the city submits its setoff request to the state tax commission or any successor agency the notice shall include a statement which sets forth the administrative appeal procedures available to the debtor provided by this section and any alternatives available to the debtor which may avoid the setoff the city shall promptly notify the debtor when the liability out of which the setoff arises has been satisfied b if a debtor disputes that he owes a delinquent debt or the amount of a delinquent debt the debtor may submit a written request for review of the debt to the city manager the city manager shall review all of the relevant facts to determine whether the debt is owed and whether the amount claimed by the city is correct if the city manager determines the amount setoff exceeds the amount properly due the city shall refund the appropriate amount to the debtor if the city manager determines that the city is entitled to no part of the amount setoff the city shall refund the entire amount plus any administrative fee retained by the state tax commission or any successor agency to the debtor if a tax refund has been setoff based upon an error committed by the city the city shall pay the debtor interest as required by the setoff debt collection act if the debtors request is received and resolved prior to a setoff request being submitted to the state tax commission or any successor agency the amount of the delinquent debt owned shall be adjusted accordingly the city manager may decline to consider a debtors request received more than 30 days after the city sends the debtor the notice required by subsection c of this section c upon receipt by the city of proceeds collected on its behalf by the state tax commission or any successor agency together with an accounting therefor the city shall credit the debtors obligation and notify the debtor in writing of the amount of the setoff and the balance due if any  collection agreement upon a resolution being adopted by city council the city manager may enter into an agreement with the municipal association of south carolina or any other authorized agency or entity for services related to collection of delinquent debt pursuant to the setoff debt collection act  collection costs charge to the extent allowed by law the city manager may set and assess against delinquent debtors a charge for the estimated actual costs to the city of collecting debts pursuant to this division and the charge shall be added to and become part of such delinquent debt if the city contracts with another agency or entity for services related to this collection procedure the collection charges of that agency or entity shall be added to and become part of the delinquent debt to the extent allowed by law in the same manner as the city charge the city manager shall notify the city council of the schedule of property values within the area in which the incentives are offered and the city as a whole  b increased revenues from property taxes business license fees permit fees utility revenues and other fees imposed by the city from other properties within the area in which incentives are offered  c greater amenities for the benefit of the citys citizens  and d increased tourism and commercial activity within the area in which the incentives are offered and the city as a whole goals means the objectives of the city in offering the incentives which generally are a to promote the construction of new buildings or the rehabilitation of existing buildings within specific areas of the city  b to support the establishment of the categories of new businesses within these areas that the council determines will significantly increase the overall commercial activity within specific areas of the city  and c to increase employment opportunities within the city incentive shall mean a grant of any inducement having monetary value by the city that is offered to a person firm or corporation to pursue a project that encourages private investment andor the creationretention of jobs the incentive incentives b incentive recipient where the project sponsor is the developer of a project but does not own andor operate the business or businesses located therein that are responsible for the payment increase or decrease yeartoyear as the council sees fit but subject to monitoring by the city to ensure compliance with the terms of any incentive agreement the council may offer incentives in recipient 12 months following the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project  2 up to 50 percent of building permit fees collected by the city permit fees to be reimbursed to the recipient 12 months following the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project  3 up to 50 percent of business license fees collected by the city business license fees for as many as five years to be reimbursed to the payor of the business license fees at the annual anniversary of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project for which a business license has been issued provided the recipient has continued to operate the business for which the business license fees were paid for the entirety of such year  4 such other incentives that the council at its discretion on a casebycase basis determines are appropriate given the amount or type of investment made by the project sponsor d state incentive programs the council may include within any package of incentives or as a standalone incentive for incity project any incentive authorized by statute state incentive programs  1 8132018 eligibility criteria a general eligibility criteria except for those incentives authorized under a state incentive program in order for a project to be eligible to receive incentives the council shall determine and make specific findings in the ordinance approving any incentive agreement that the project meets or upon completion will meet each of the following criteria 1 the project is consistent with the city of aiken comprehensive plan as it may be amended and updated from time to time the comprehensive plan  2 the manner in which the project will advance the goals of the city  3 the project upon completion and continued operation for the term of the incentives authorized will result in the realization of benefits to the city and its citizens that exceed the value of the incentives provided including a description of the tangible and intangible benefits that are expected to accrue to the city and its citizens as a result of a project  4 absent the provision of incentives the project would be unlikely to occur or unlikely to occur at the level or scale contemplated by the proposed project sponsor  and 5 the project consists of a business or businesses that are substantially devoted to one or more of the following uses 1 retail uses  2 tourismrelated business or activities  3 corporate headquarters  4 research and development  5 high technology growth businesses  and 6 other uses as may be determined by the council that are consistent with the goals and the comprehensive plan where the project includes multiple businesses or uses at least 50 percent of the commercial space comprising the project must be occupied by one or more of the above listed uses b additional criteria the council may in its discretion and on a casebycase basis include within an incentive agreement any other eligibility criteria including without limitation capital investment and job creation benchmarks that must be met upon completion of a project in order to ensure that the goals are met and that the project provides benefits to the city and its citizens that creation have been fully achieved or otherwise completed 2 where benchmarks such as the number of jobs created or the continuous operation of a business are to be met continuously over a period of time the project sponsor shall provide to the city on an annual basis sufficient proof that the project has continuously achieved or otherwise complied with such requirements upon the anniversary of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy 3 if at any time after completion of a project or at any time within the period of time during which a project is granted incentives a project fails to achieve or otherwise comply with any benchmark or other requirement the council may at its discretion and on a casebycase basis a declare the incentive agreement null and void and refuse to grant any future incentives  or b decrease the amount of incentives based upon the actual direct and indirect benefits of the project to the city and its citizens d administration of program the administration spayed or neutered pet owners shall be so notified of this provision in the annual pet license renewal notices given by the city the city will maintain these written certifications in its pet tag reports d any handicapped owner of a dog which is used by the owner as an aid for seeing hearing or other physical purposes and which is specially trained for such purposes by a recognized service organization shall be required to obtain a city tag but shall be exempt from paying the tag fee e the city tag issued for a pet that is not microchipped shall be attached to a collar or harness and worn by the dog at all times except as provided as follows 1 while within the confines of the walls of a building or a completely and securely fencedin yard area on the owners premises a dog is not required to wear a harness or collar with city tag attached but the owner shall have the rabies tag and city tag available and immediately produce them upon request of an animal control officer rabies control officer or public safety officer 2 a hunting or stock dog and show dog while being worked conditioned groomed andor shown under the direct control of its owner is not required to wear the city tag while engaged in such activities but the owner shall have the city tag and rabies tag available at the site of such activity for inspection and immediately produce them upon request of an animal control officer rabies control officer or public safety officer f a kennel license must be obtained for every kennel a kennel license shall also be required to be obtained for any location which houses an exotic animal vicious animal or an identified hybrid the kennel license shall be $2500 per year and shall be required in addition to the city tag set forth in subsection a above kennel licenses shall be required annually and shall expire on june 30 of each year authorized agents of the city are empowered to enter upon the premises of any kennel subject to this section and to make animal care inspections it shall be unlawful for any such person to fail or refuse to permit these inspections of care received by animals or to interfere with these inspections in any manner  11142005 state law reference pets to be inoculated sc  vicious animal a it shall be unlawful for the owner of a vicious animal to permit the animal to leave a securely enclosed and confined area located on the owners premises unless the animal is securely muzzled and leashed or securely enclosed and confined in a cage or similar container so that it may be controlled by the owner b when a person has an animal that is vicious it shall be unlawful for that person to fail to report the animal to an animal control officer or city public safety officer c any person convicted of an offense under this section shall have the animal spayed or neutered by a date specified by the presiding judge and in the discretion of the court forfeit all right title and interest in the animal and an animal control officer upon order of the court specifying a date for compliance shall euthanize the animal or have the animal euthanized d the provisions of this section shall not apply to guard dogs owned and used exclusively by licensed security services or dogs used by law enforcement agencies  11142005 state law reference regulation of dangerous animals sc  et seq restraint of dogs and atlarge dogs a all dogs shall be kept under restraints at all times by their owners while within the city and off the owners premises the owner of a dog when taking it off the owners premises must restrain the dog by placing it in a secure enclosure or by securely restraining it on a leash under the physical control of the owner it shall be unlawful for the owner to fail to so restrain a dog while off the owners premises a dog off the owners premises and not restrained as required by this section shall be deemed to be an animal atlarge b dogs that are participating in or training for hunting events obedience trials conformation shows tracking tests herding trials terrier trials or lure courses under the direct control of their owner shall not be considered animals atlarge and are exempt from the requirements of subsection a of this section c any owner whose dog is found atlarge within the city shall forfeit all right title interest and ownership in the dog subject to the procedures in this chapter  11142005 state law reference authority of city to prohibit running at large sc  sanitation the owner of every pet shall be responsible for the immediate removal of all excretions deposited by the pet at any place off the owners premises  11142005 impoundment a animals whose owners are in violation of this chapter shall be taken into custody by an animal control officer or public safety officer and impounded in the animal control shelter b animals whose owners are known shall be held at the animal control shelter for ten business days unless released earlier to the owner the animal control officer shall notify the owner that unless the animal is claimed within such time it may be euthanized or released for adoption approved agency if the animal control officer cannot contact the owner in person or by telephone within 24 hours of the animals impoundment a notification letter shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address if any of the owner c animals whose owners are not known shall be held at the animal control shelter for five calendar days and if unclaimed the animal control officer may euthanize such animals or release them for adoption approved agency d an animal may be released from impoundment after payment by the owner of all fees  verification of a current rabies inoculation  and presentation of a valid city tag before an animal is released from impoundment the owner of the animal must pay the city the currently required fee for each impoundment in addition to impoundment fees the owner shall pay the per diem board fee established or approved by the city there will be an additional impoundment fee for female pets in heat the owner shall be responsible for all fees whether the animal is reclaimed or not  and it shall be unlawful for the owner to fail to pay such fees  11142005 nuisance animals the action of an animal constitutes a public nuisance under this section when it disturbs the rights threatens the safety or damages a member of the general public or interferes with the ordinary use and enjoyment of his property or public property or areas it shall be unlawful for any person to own keep possess or maintain an animal in such a manner as to constitute or allow it to become a public nuisance in addition the following acts or actions by an owner of any animal are hereby declared to be a public nuisance under this section and to be unlawful 1 failure to exercise sufficient restraint necessary to control an animal as required by the provisions of this chapter 2 allowing or permitting an animal to damage the property of anyone other than its owner including but not limited to turning over garbage containers or damaging vegetation 3 maintaining a vicious animal 4 maintaining animals in unsanitary conditions which result in offensive odors or are dangerous to the animal or the public health welfare or safety 5 maintaining his premises or other property in a manner that is offensive annoying or dangerous to the health safety or welfare of the public because of the number density or location of the animals on the owners premises or other property 6 allowing or permitting an animal to bark whine howl yowl crow or cackle continuously for ten minutes or longer or make other noise in such a manner so as to result in a serious annoyance or interference with the reasonable use and enjoyment of adjoining or nearby properties 7 keeping an animal that is diseased and dangerous to public health 8 keeping an animal that habitually or repeatedly chases snaps at attacks or barks at pedestrians bicycles or vehicles 9 failing to confine or control a female pet in heat in such a manner as not to create a nuisance by attracting other animals  11142005 injured or diseased animals it shall be control officer public safety officer or other official of the city any animal received by the animal control shelter in critical condition from wounds injuries or disease may be destroyed if the owner cannot be located within two hours of receipt of the animal at the shelter if the animal is in severe pain it may be euthanized immediately at the discretion of the animal control superintendent or an animal control officer  11142005 animal bites and quarantine of animals a the breaking of skin of a human being by an animal shall be considered an animal bite case all animal bite cases shall be reported to an animal control officer public safety officer or other official of the city by anyone having knowledge thereof during nonbusiness hours the report shall be made to the 911 emergency center the animal bite report shall be made as soon as possible and in no case more than 24 hours after bite animal control officers shall assist in making animal bite reports but the initial responsibility is that of the owner of the animal involved or believed to be involved and the person bitten to report the incident to the city it shall be unlawful for an animal owner or the person bitten to fail to make the report required by this section b the owner of any animal that has physical contact with a suspected rabid wild animal shall promptly notify the city of the incident c any animal which has bitten a human being or is suspected of being rabid shall be quarantined by the city for at least ten days and no such animal shall be released from quarantine or euthanized until the animal has been examined by a licensed veterinarian or rabies control officer and determined not to have symptoms of rabies the rabies control officer is authorized to require that the animal be quarantined at the animal control shelter or may at the request of the animal owner allow the animal to be quarantined in a facility operated by a licensed veterinarian the owner is responsible for all board and veterinary medical costs incurred during the quarantine the animal may be quarantined at the owners residence at the discretion of the rabies control officer  11142005 state law injured animals a it shall be unlawful for an owner or any other person to willfully injure or kill any animal by any means causing it unnecessary fright or pain and it shall further be unlawful for the owner or any other person by neglect or otherwise to cause or allow any animal to endure pain suffering or injury acts constituting violations of this section include but are not limited to the following 1 failure to provide adequate shelter from inclement weather 2 failure to provide food for a period of more than 24 hours andor water or other necessary care for more than 12 hours 3 abandoning any animal on private or public property 4 leaving or exposing any poisonous substance food or drink for man animal or fowl or aiding or abetting any person in so doing except insect or rodent poison when used in compliance with the product directions for control of insects or rodents 5 baiting attacking with violence provoking or harassing an animal or causing an animal to engage in fights with or among other animals or between animals and humans nothing in the foregoing sentence however shall prohibit the lawful training of guard or law enforcement dogs or other animals provided it does not violate other provisions of this chapter the city code or the laws of this state 6 riding animals beyond their endurance limits requiring animals to pull or operate any carriage or other animal powered vehicles beyond these animals endurance limits overloading animals making animals carry loads or operate animal powered vehicles when they or the animals are overloaded torturing tormenting depriving of necessary sustenance cruelly beating mutilating or cruelly killing animals or causing or procuring these actions to be done b any owner whose animal has been subjected to a violation of this section by the owner shall forfeit all right title interest and ownership in the animal subject to the procedures in this chapter and the animal shall be impounded until the animal control superintendent determines that the circumstances of the cruelty or neglect by the owner have been remedied upon conviction in municipal court of a violation of this section the sentence imposed by the municipal judge may include the permanent forfeiture of the animal c it shall be unlawful for an owner or person to tether a dog to a stationary object or mobile device in violation of this section persons using tethering devices to control their dogs must comply with the following regulations 1 no person shall tether a dog to a stationary object or to a mobile device including but not limited to a trolley or pulley by means of a a tether that does not allow such dog to walk at least fifteen feet excluding the length of such dog as measured from the tip of such dogs nose to the base of such dogs tail in any one direction b a tether that does not have workable swivels on both ends to prevent twisting and tangling unless a person is in the presence of such dog c a coat hanger choke collar prongtype collar head halter or any other collar halter or device that is not specifically designed or properly fitted for the restraint of such dog d a tether that has weights attached or that contains metal chain links more than onequarter of an inch thick e a tether that allows such dog to reach an object or hazard including but not limited to a window sill edge of a pool fence public road or highway porch or terrace railing that poses a risk of injury or strangulation to such dog if such dog walks into or jumps over such object or hazard unless a person is in the presence of such dog f no chain or tether shall weigh more than oneeighth of the dogs body weight 2 a person owning or keeping a dog confined shall provide the dog with access to clean water and appropriate dog shelter the dog shelter shall allow the dog to remain dry and protected from the elements the shelter shall be an appropriate size for the dog and enable the dog to stand lie down and turn comfortably the structure shall be structurally sound and in good repair suitable drainage shall be provided so that water ice or waste is not standing in or around the shelter 3 the provisions of subdivisions 1 and 2 of this subsection shall not be construed to apply to a any veterinary practice licensed pursuant to state law that tethers a dog in the course of such veterinary practice b any exhibition show contest or other temporary event in which the skill breeding or stamina of such dog is judged or examined c any exhibition class training session or other temporary event in which such dog is used in a lawful manner to hunt a species of wildlife during the hunting season for such species of wildlife or in which such dog receives training in a lawful manner to hunt such species of wildlife d the temporary tethering of a dog at any camping or recreation area as expressly authorized by the commissioner of energy and environmental protection or e the temporary tethering of a dog at a grooming facility in the course of grooming such dog 4 no person shall tether a dog outdoors to a stationary object or to a mobile device including but not limited to a trolley or a pulley when a weather advisory or warning is issued by local state or federal authorities or when outdoor environmental conditions including but not limited to extreme heat cold wind rain snow or hail pose an adverse risk to the health or safety of such dog based on such dogs breed age or physical condition unless tethering is for a duration of no longer than fifteen minutes d it shall be unlawful for an owner or person to confine any animal in a motor vehicle that is done in a manner that places the animal in a life threatening or extreme healththreatening situation by exposing it to a prolonged period of extreme heat or cold without proper ventilation or other protection from such heat or cold in order to protect the health and safety of an animal an animal control officer law enforcement officer or fire fighter who has probable cause to believe that this section is being violated shall have the authority to enter such motor vehicle by any reasonable means necessary under the circumstances after making a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other responsible person in the event that the owner or other responsible person cannot be located the animal control officer law enforcement officer or fire fighter may take the following actions 1 take all steps that are reasonably necessary to remove an animal from a motor vehicle if the animals health safety or wellbeing appears to be in immediate danger from heat cold or lack of adequate ventilation and the conditions could reasonably be expected to cause extreme suffering or death 2 remove an animal from a motor vehicle if the animals safety appears to be in immediate danger from heat cold lack of adequate ventilation lack of food or water or other circumstances that could reasonably be expected to cause suffering disability or death to the animal an animal control officer law enforcement officer or fire fighter may enter the motor vehicle for the sole purpose of rescue or release of the animal and may not search the vehicle unless otherwise permitted by law 3 a law enforcement or animal control officer who removes an animal in accordance with this section shall in a secure and conspicuous location on or within the motor vehicle leave written notice bearing the officers or agents name and office and the address of the location where the animal may be retrieved the owner may retrieve the animal only after payment of all charges that have accrued for the maintenance care medical treatment and impoundment of the animal 4 a law enforcement or animal control officer who removes an animal from a motor vehicle pursuant to this section is immune from criminal or civil liability that might otherwise result from the removal  11142005   1exh a 6112018 penalties it shall be unlawful for any
