sale  professional corporations and other entities where legal medical dental engineering architectural or other professional services are delivered  and private clubs employee shall mean a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages commission goods or services in kind or like compensation and it shall also mean a person who volunteers his or her services for a nonprofit entity employer means a person business partnership association corporation including a municipal corporation trust or nonprofit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is enclosed on all sides by walls or windows exclusive of doorways which extend from the floor to the ceiling including stationary structures and mobile public conveyances it does not mean an area open at least 50 percent to the outdoors and not including any roof or ceiling over it in this calculation health care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of persons having diseases whether physical mental or emotional or other medical physiological or psychological conditions including but not limited to hospitals rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics including weight control clinics nursing homes except as otherwise permitted herein homes for the aging or chronically ill laboratories and offices of surgeons chiropractors physical therapists physicians dentists and all specialists within these professions this definition shall include all waiting rooms hallways private rooms semiprivate rooms and wards within health care facilities infiltrate means to permeate an enclosed area by passing walls ceilings floors windows or ventilation systems to the extent that an individual can smell second hand smoke place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer that employees normally frequent during the course of employment including but not limited to work areas employee lounges restrooms conference rooms meeting rooms classrooms employee cafeterias hallways and vehicles a private residence is not a place of employment for purposes of this article unless it is used as a childcare adult day care or health care facility nor is a private passenger motor vehicle a place of employment when used in the performance of employment responsibilities provided it is not being used as public conveyance private club means an organization whether incorporated or not which is the owner lessee or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes or for purposes of benefiting particular club members and their guests which is operated solely for a recreational fraternal social patriotic political benevolent or athletic purpose but not for pecuniary gain and which only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation the affairs and management of the organization are conducted by a board of directors executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting the organization has established bylaws andor a constitution to govern its activities the organization has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 usc establishments which are in fact operating as bars restaurants or entertainment venues primarily for the pecuniary benefit of the owner or chief operating officer or other person having substantial control shall not be treated as private clubs under this article public place means an area to which the public is invited or to which the public is permitted to have access including but not limited to the indoor areas of banks bars educational facilities health care facilities hotel and motel lobbies laundromats public transportation facilities reception areas restaurants retail food production and marketing establishments retail service establishments retail stores shopping malls theaters or waiting rooms a private club is a public place when being used for a function to which the general public is allowed entry a private residence is not a public place unless it is used as a childcare adult day care or health care facility restaurant means the indoor areas of a eating establishment including but not limited to coffee shops cafeterias sandwich stands ice cream parlors and private and public school cafeterias which gives or offers for sale food to the public guests or employees as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere the term restaurant shall include a bar area within the restaurant retail tobacco store means a retail store utilized primarily for the sale of tobacco products and accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental the term specifically includes cigar bars which are establishments licensed for the onpremises sale of beer wine and alcoholic beverages as well as some food service but the term does not include any establishment which is primarily a bar or restaurant and which undertakes to make retail offerings of tobacco products as a means of circumventing the purposes of this article second hand smoke means smoke emitted from lighted smoldering or burning tobacco when the person smoking is not inhaling smoke emitted at the mouthpiece during puff drawing and smoke exhaled by the person smoking service line means an indoor line in which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind whether or not the service involves the exchange of money shopping mall means an enclosed public plaza promenade walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments smoking means inhaling exhaling burning or carrying any lighted cigar cigarette pipe or other lighted tobacco product and any electronic cigarette in any manner or in any form  7142008   1 4242017 application to cityowned facilities areas within places of employment without exception including but not limited to common work areas auditoriums classrooms conference and meeting rooms private offices elevators hallways medical facilities cafeterias employee lounges stairs restrooms vehicles used for the conveyance of the public but not including vehicles used in performing employment responsibilities when the sole occupants and users are persons who smoke b this prohibition on smoking shall be communicated by employers to all existing employees by the effective date of this article and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment  7142008 where smoking not regulated notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary the following areas shall be exempt from the provisions of sections 2267 and 2268 of this article 1 private residences except when used as a licensed childcare adult day care or health care facility 2 hotel and motel rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article the status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed except to add additional nonsmoking rooms 3 retail tobacco stores provided that smoke from these places does not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article 4 private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes and longterm care facilities that are occupied by one or more persons all of whom are smokers and have requested in writing to be placed in a room where smoking is permitted  provided that smoke from these places does not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article 5 private clubs that have no employees except when being used for a function to which the general public is admitted  7142008 declaration of establishment as nonsmoking notwithstanding any other provision of this article an owner operator manager or other person in control of an establishment facility or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment facility or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place smoking also shall be prohibited in any place in which a no smoking sign is posted  7142008 nonretaliation  nonwaiver of rights a no person or employer shall discharge refuse to hire or in any manner retaliate against an employee applicant for employment or customer because that employee applicant or customer exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article b an employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party  7142008 enforcement a this article shall be enforced by the office of the city manager or an authorized designee b notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the city c any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the office of the city manager d the building codes division fire department or their designees shall while an establishment is undergoing otherwise mandated inspections inspect for compliance with this article e an owner manager operator or employee of an establishment regulated by this article shall inform persons violating this article of the appropriate provisions thereof f notwithstanding any other provision of this article an employee or member of the public may bring legal action against a person business or organization in violation of this article to enforce this article g in addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section the city or any person aggrieved by the failure of the owner operator manager or other person in control of a public place or a place of employment to comply with the provisions of this article may apply for injunctive relief to enforce those provisions in any court of competent jurisdiction  7142008 violations and penalties a a person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction punishable by a fine of not less than $1000 nor more than $2500 b a person who owns manages operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction punishable by a fine of not less than $1000 nor more than $2500 c in addition to the fines established by this section repeated violations of this article by a person who owns manages operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any occupancy permit or business license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred d violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance which may be abated by the city by restraining order preliminary and permanent injunction or other means provided for by law and the city may take action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement e each day of a continuing violation of this article shall be considered a separate and distinct offense f no ordinance summons nor any enforcement action shall be taken under this ordinance prior to   7142008 public education the city will engage in a continuing program to explain and clarify the purposes and requirements of this article to citizens affected by it and to guide ownersoperators and managers in their compliance with it the program may include publication of a brochure for affected businesses and individuals explaining the provisions of this article  7142008 governmental agency cooperation the city shall annually request other governmental and educational agencies having facilities within the city to establish local operating procedures in cooperation and compliance with this article this includes urging all federal state county city and school district agencies to update their existing smoking control regulations to be consistent with the current health findings regarding secondhand smoke  7142008 other applicable laws this article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws  7142008 interpretation for intent it is the intent of council to prohibit smoking whenever the private choice of smoking intrudes or has the capacity to intrude upon the right of persons concerned about protecting their own rights to be free from the hazards and inconvenience of secondhand smoke in indoor places where they work stand sit walk dine drink read study or engage in entertainment all provisions shall be construed to achieve these purposes  7142008 parades and other assemblies footnotes  1  cross reference streets and sidewalks ch 36  driving in under this chapter b it shall be unlawful for any demonstrator or person picketing or parading to interfere with or cause to be interfered with any person or vehicle in the act of entering or walking on any sidewalk street road or public or private business or building within the corporate limits of the city c it shall be unlawful for any person engaged in any demonstration picketing or parading in the city to fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of any public safety officer of the city while such officer is about his lawful duties  time limit for parades pickets and demonstrators it shall be unlawful for pickets or demonstrators or parades to extend their operation beyond the time limit set forth in the permit issued to them by the director of public safety  limitation on signs carried by pickets demonstrators and paraders it shall be unlawful for a picket demonstrator or parader to use any sign larger than three feet wide and four feet high and which is not carried by one person special permission to carry larger signs in parades may be granted where the normal flow of traffic has been detoured and is under control of the department of public safety  demonstrators and pickets to leave space for pedestrians and motorists all persons demonstrating or picketing pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter shall leave a clear space of at least ten feet in all directions for pedestrians and motorists  pickets and demonstrators not to sit or lie down it shall be unlawful for pickets or demonstrators to sit or lie down while picketing or demonstrating so as to interfere with the normal flow of pedestrians or vehicular traffic  disorderly conduct by participants in group gatherings it shall be unlawful for any person who is affiliated with any organized group gathering to conduct himself in a disorderly manner or in such manner as to disturb the peace and tranquility of the city  interfering with parades generally no person shall unreasonably hamper obstruct impede or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade  driving vehicle no driver of a vehicle shall the following information 1 the name address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade 2 if the parade is proposed to be conducted for on behalf of or by an organization the date such parade is proposed to be conducted    1132011 standards for issuance the director of public safety shall issue a parade permit when from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained he finds that 1 the conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route 2 the conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of public safety officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city 3 the concentration of persons animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas 4 the conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire fighting equipment en route to a fire 5 the conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance 6 the parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route 7 the parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product goods or event and is not designed to be held purely for private profit  time of issuance or denial  notice of denial the director of public safety shall issue or deny a parade permit within two days after the filing of the application therefor if the director of public safety disapproves the application and denies the permit he shall mail to the applicant within three days after the date upon which the application was filed a notice of his action stating the reasons for his denial of the permit  appeal of denial any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council the appeal shall be taken within five days after the notice provided for in section 2434 the city council shall act upon the appeal within 15 days after its receipt  issuance of alternate permit the director of public safety in denying an application for a parade permit shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant an applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall within three days after notice of the action of the director of public safety file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police an alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article  contents each parade permit shall state the following information 1 starting time 2 maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade 3 the portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade  compliance with conditions  permit to be located within a residential zoning district and which event is sponsored and conducted solely by owners in or residents of the block and is not for any commercial or advertising purpose or for profit gathering on premises he owns rents occupies resides in or has control of after having been notified by a city public safety officer to terminate the party because activities relating to or arising upon a form provided by the city and shall be prepared by the applicant and submitted to the director of the department of public safety or his designee setting forth the following information 1 the name residence and home and business telephone numbers of each person sponsoring the event  2 the location date beginning and ending hours and purpose of such temporary street closure  3 a brief explanation of the activities which will occur during the event  and 4 such other information as the director of the department of public safety deems reasonably necessary to carry out the provisions of this article  time of filing the application for the permit required by this article shall be filed with the director of the department of public safety or his designee not less than seven days prior to the scheduled date of such event the failure to file an application within such period may be grounds for denial of a permit  permit conditions any permit granted under this article shall contain such terms and conditions as the director of the department of public safety or his designee determines are reasonably necessary to reduce or minimize the dangers and hazards to vehicular or pedestrian traffic or public health safety tranquility morals or welfare including but not limited to changes or limitations in time duration numbers of participants noise sound or any other relevant matter  standards for issuance of permit a permit authorized by this article shall be issued by the director of the department of public safety or his designee when from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained he concludes that the following circumstances exist 1 the time duration size and nature of the temporary street closure the block party or other event will not substantially disrupt the orderly and safe movement of vehicular or pedestrian traffic  2 the concentration of persons will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection or ambulance service or the operation of any established commercial business government or public operations or institutions in the area  and 3 the nature and time of the event will not unduly interfere with or disturb the reasonable tranquility of adjoining residential areas  revocation of permit any permit for a temporary street closure block party or other event issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the director of the department of public safety or his designee at any time when by reason of emergency disaster disorder riot traffic conditions violation of this article or any permit conditions violations of any other laws or ordinances or undue burden on public services he determines that the health safety tranquility morals or welfare of the public requires such revocation the determination of such revocation may be delivered to the applicant if the applicant can be reasonably located orally or in writing by personal contact personal service or telephone  appeal from denial of permit any person aggrieved by the denial of a block party permit shall have the right to appeal to the city council the appeal shall be taken within five days after establish objective criteria relating to the following surrounding uses likely to generate a demand for periodicals and other material customarily supplied distances between locations and the visual compatibility of newsracks and modular newsracks with surrounding facades and streetscape improvements c design requirements no person other than the city shall place or use for distribution of material any newsrack or modular newsrack on any public sidewalk public park or other public space owned by the city in the central business district in determining design requirements the city manager shall consider compatibility of design features with prevailing facade treatments and with streetscape improvements to the full extent modular newsracks having such features are reasonably available on the market d definitions for purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply central business district the district bounded on the south by colleton avenue then turning north on laurens street then turning west on park avenue then turning north on hayne avenue then turning west on hayne avenue then turning north on greenville street then turning east on abbeville avenue then turning south on union street and returning to colleton avenue the district shall include all properties within the above described and all properties on both sides of the streets and avenues that comprise the central business district this definition shall apply for purposes of this section only and is not to be confused with the downtown business district referred to in the city of aiken zoning any industry standard selfservice or coin operated machine which dispenses newspapers periodicals brochures pamphlets and like material to the general public modular newsrack one industry standard structure composed of a group of individual publication dispensing cabinets mounted as single cabinets or as cabinets in multiple cabinet configurations publisher a person or corporation or other legal entity who engages in the business of publishing newspapers periodicals brochures pamphlets and like material e delegation of duties the city manager may delegate in whole or in part the city managers duties under this section to one or more city employees f ownership of modular newsracks the city shall own all of the modular newsracks authorized by the city manager under this section the city shall be responsible for the upkeep repair and replacement of modular newsracks g allocation of locations the city manager shall develop written criteria to allocate the limited modular newsracks locations available for periodicals and other material the criteria shall be non discriminatory among publishers but may make reasonable limitations on the number of publications that any one publisher or its affiliates may have at any one location when spaces at that location are limited in number the city manager may also implement reasonable regulations to promote the full utilization of modular newsrack spaces and to require the forfeiture of modular newsrack spaces when they are not fully utilized the city manager may make limitations on the lettering logos and graphics that appear on the modular newsracks but shall allow a reasonable basis for publications contained within spaces to be readily identified the initial draft of these regulations is attached hereto as exhibit b and is set out following this section h permit not a property right the permits for the use of public modular newsrack space as provided for under this section are not property rights or entitlements of any distributor of material found in the modular newsracks  1282008 exhibit a exhibit b newsrack unit regulations allocation of newsrack unit spaces the total number of public spaces on the right of way or other cityowned property to be made available for modular newsracks in the central business district as defined in section 3612 of the aiken city  shall be allocated by the following criteria 1 the city of aiken will purchase and install modular newsracks for the locations originally approved by city council the city will lease space on a biannual basis to publications originally approved by city council there will be a minimum of 400 feet between each modular newsrack location which may be comprised of more than one modular newsrack 2 no later than may 15 of each year following the initial allocation of spaces all publishers interested in leasing unoccupied modular newsrack space shall submit to the city manager a request identifying the number of spaces and locations requested no later than june 1 of each year the city manager shall designate the number of spaces if any a requesting publisher shall have at any location effective july 1 the space so allocated subject to the terms and conditions of these regulations shall be held by the permittee for two consecutive fiscal years at a cost per year to be determined and based upon the actual cost to the city amortized over a fiveyear period 3 if all spaces at all locations are available to meet all publishers requests as submitted then the city managers office shall issue space permits as requested before newsrack spaces are allocated the publisher will agree to remove all of its personal newsracks from the central business district within ten days of receiving its space from the city if the publisher does not remove its racks within this time the city will be authorized to remove the racks 4 if there are insufficient spaces at a location to meet all new requests for available spaces as submitted then the city managers office shall allocate by lottery for the locations where there are insufficient spaces 5 all publishers failing to receive a space at a particular location shall be put on a waiting list for that location for the applicable year in the sequence their names were drawn for that location if spaces at the location become available during the year then they shall be made available to publishers in the sequence their names appear on the waiting list for the location 6 no publisher may utilize more than 50 percent of the available modular newsrack space at any one location unless there is a space not being utilized at the location but each publisher may offer more than one publication in the spaces provided 7 publishers not participating in the may 15 application may be placed on the waiting list behind those already on the list and they shall be placed in the order their requests are received 8 a publications permit for a modular newsrack space is not transferable 9 all publishers must keep stocked the modular newsrack spaces allocated to them if the city checks randomly and finds a space not stocked two out of four times over a four week period the occupancy can be terminated provided there is a publisher on the waiting list for the location the city must keep the modular newsracks in good working order and good appearance 10 in the event a publisher desires to utilize a coin operated device for the purpose of collecting money for their publication the publisher will be responsible for procuring the coin operated device and will be responsible for the upkeep maintenance and repair of these coin operated devices 11 the city manager shall have the ability to amend these regulations from time to time with a minimum of 15 days written notice to all tenants  1282008 secs 36133630  reserved article ii  street names naming system established a there is hereby established a uniform system of street naming in the city and all streets avenues and other dedicated public ways shall be named in accordance with the provisions of this article b all streets and other public ways running in the same direction and having a deviation of not more than 125 feet from the nearest parallel street shall carry the same name unless special circumstances make such a plan impracticable or not feasible c all west streets shall carry the designation avenue and all south streets shall carry the designation street d that part of any street ending in a deadend or culdesac shall carry the designation place e the name terrace shall be used in any residential or business development for any north and south alley street which bisects or crosses a nominal block or series of blocks and the name lane shall be used for any such east and west alley street f no street established or named shall bear a name in conflict with the general directions set out in this article  preparation of naming plan by planning commission a for the purpose of clarifying and systematizing the street naming pattern in the city and to implement the application of the provisions set forth in section 3631 the planning commission is hereby authorized to prepare and present to the city council a complete plan for the naming of all streets avenues and public ways within the city which shall be adhered to except where a conflict or duplication exists the planning commission shall follow the general plan set forth in section 3631 and such other rules as are set forth in this article b in preparing the plan under this section if the planning commission shall find an existing street now carrying more than one name it shall recommend that such street shall bear the name under which it currently travels the longest distance both inside and outside of the city limits unless circumstances indicate that another and different name would be desirable the planning commission may hold public hearings at which interested property owners may express their views concerning the changing of the name or names of any street  state law reference approval of street names sc  subdivision plats to bear report of planning commission as to street names every subdivision plat submitted to the city council for its approval shall bear upon its face the report of the planning commission of the proper names of any and all streets avenues and public ways dedicated to public use within the jurisdiction of the city council and shall first be checked by the planning commission as to their names under the provisions of this article  street naming and renaming recommendations of planning commission the planning commission shall recommend to the city council any change in the name or the naming of existing or newly established streets within the limits of the city  secs 36353660  reserved article iii  street numbers for lots and buildings footnotes  2  cross reference buildings and building regulations ch 10 system established  compliance with article there is hereby established a uniform system for numbering parcels of land fronting on all streets avenues and public ways in the city and all houses and other buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article  baselines designated a richland avenue shall constitute the baseline for numbering parcels along all streets running northerly and southerly  and chesterfield street and whiskey road as hereinafter named and established shall constitute the base line for numbering parcels along all streets running easterly and westerly b each parcel north of richland avenue and facing a street running in a northerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location north of such base street c each parcel south of richland avenue and facing a street running in a southerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location south of such base street d each parcel east of chesterfield street and whiskey road and facing a street running in an easterly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location east of such base street e each parcel east of chesterfield street and whiskey road and facing a street running in a westerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location west of such base street f all parcels on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as parcels on northerly and southerly streets if the diagonal street runs more from the north to the south and the same rule shall apply on easterly and westerly streets if the diagonal street runs more from the east to the west all parcels on diagonal streets having a deviation of exactly 45 degrees shall be numbered the same as parcels on northerly and southerly streets  lot numbering to begin at baseline  one number for each 20 feet the numbering of parcels on each street shall begin at the baseline all numbers shall be assigned on the basis of one number for every 20 feet of street frontage  odd and even numbers all parcels on the north and east side of each street running from the base street shall bear even numbers all parcels on the south and west side of each street running from the base street shall bear odd numbers  numbering of lots facing streets not extending to baseline all parcels facing streets not extending the baseline shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street had extended to the baseline  numbers and directional symbols for streets avenues etc in addition to lot numbers a in addition to the numbers placed on each parcel as heretofore provided all streets avenues and other public ways within the city are hereby given numbers and directional symbols according to their distance and direction from the two base streets set forth in section 3662 b all streets east of chesterfield street and whiskey road and north of richland avenue shall carry the designation northeast ne c all streets west of chesterfield street and whiskey road and north of richland avenue shall carry the designation northwest nw d all streets east of chesterfield street and whiskey road and south of richland avenue shall carry the designation southeast se e all streets west of chesterfield street and whiskey road and south of richland avenue shall carry the designation southwest sw f each block shall bear a number or numbers corresponding to the distance of the block from the base street each block parallel to the base street shall carry the same block number between terminating streets if the block is not parallel with either base street then its number shall vary according to the distance the block is from both base streets g each house or other building in addition to the number or numbers given it under other sections of this article shall also bear the number and direction of the street on which it is located  numbering building entrances serving separate occupants a where any building has more than one entrance serving separate occupants a separate number shall be assigned to each entrance serving a separate occupant if the building is not located on a lot parcel or tract which would permit the assignment of one number to each such entrance numerals and letters shall be used as set forth in subsection b of this section b where only one number can be assigned to any building the owner occupant or agent of such building who shall desire distinctive numbers for the upper and lower portion of the building or for any part of such building fronting on any street may use the suffix a b c and so on alphabet as may be required  assignment of numbers generally it shall be the duty of the county e911 in conjunction with the public works department to inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of any parcel as provided in this article in case of conflict as to the proper number to be assigned to any building the building official shall determine the number of such building in accordance with the plats referred to in section 3670  duty to procure and display number a whenever any house building or structure shall be erected or located in the city it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct number or numbers as designated on the plats referred to in section 3670 from the building official no building permit shall be issued for any house building or structure until the owner has procured from the building official the official number of the premises final approval of any structure erected repaired altered or modified shall be withheld by the building official until durable and proper numbers have been affixed to the structure in accord with this section b the owner occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him the number or numbers assigned under the uniform system as provided in this article the cost of the number or numbers shall be paid for by the property owner or occupant replacement of numbers shall be procured and paid for by the owner or occupant the numbers used shall be not less than 2 inches in height and shall be painted or made of a durable and clearly visible material c the numbers referred to in this section shall be conspicuously placed immediately above on or at the side of the proper door of each building  or in lieu thereof they shall be placed near the walk driveway or common entrance to such building and upon a gate post fence tree post or other appropriate place within the lot lines so as to be easily discernible from the street  plats showing proper numbers for the purpose of facilitating correct numbering a plat book of all streets avenues and public ways within the city showing the proper numbers of all parcels fronting upon all streets avenue or public ways shall be kept on file in the office of the director of public works these plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during the office hours of the department of public works duplicate copies of such plats shall be furnished to the city engineer  painting of addresses on street curbs the director of the department of public safety shall promulgate written regulations for the voluntary painting of street address numbers on street curbs in the city these regulations shall include requirements providing for the clear visibility of such numbers during all hours of the day uniform standards for the sizes of the numbers the color and type of paint or paints which may be used therefor the written permission of the owner or his agent for the painting and the person or company providing the service notifying the owner or his agent in writing that it or he is not acting on behalf of the city in providing the service and that the painting of such numbers on curbs is not required by the city the display of the street address numbers as allowed by this section does not relieve the owner of the duty to display those numbers as required by section 3669  secs 36723690  reserved article iv  assessments for permanent improvements footnotes  3  state law reference assessments for street and sidewalk improvements sc  et seq petition by abutting owners  plans and specifications  assessment roll generally  etc when permanent improvements of any streets or sidewalks in the city are to be made they shall be done in the following manner upon written petition by and the consent of twothirds in number of the owners of the abutting property upon any streets proposed to be improved the petition to be filed with the city clerk agreeing to pay in the aggregate not to exceed onehalf of the total cost of such improvements of the street the city council shall by order direct the improvement of the street as follows the council shall determine the character of material to be used in the improvements to be made and the manner in which the improvements shall be done shall cause to be prepared accurate plans and specifications therefor and shall determine the cost of the improvements thereupon the city engineer or other person acting in his capacity shall prepare a plat of the street or part thereof showing the name of each owner of property abutting thereon with the location of the property of each and shall prepare an assessment roll showing the amount to be assessed against each particular piece or parcel of property abutting on the proposed improvement in proportion to the frontage of such property on the street  provided however that the assessments so made shall not exceed in the aggregate onehalf of the total cost of the improvement the assessment roll so prepared shall be filed with the city clerk whose duty it shall be upon receipt of such assessment roll to give notice by publication in a newspaper published in the city to all parties interested that the assessment roll is in his office and will there remain for a period of one week from the date of the publication of the notice all persons concerned during such period of one week may file in writing with the city clerk such exceptions or objections to the assessment as they may desire  rejection or ratification of assessment roll by council at the expiration of one week from the date of the notice of the completion of the assessment roll the city clerk shall refer the assessment roll to the city council together with such exceptions or objections as may have been filed thereto and the city council at its next regular meeting or at an adjourned or called meeting shall review the assessment roll together with any exceptions and shall have authority to make any correction therein deemed proper and in its discretion to reject or ratify the assessment roll upon the ratification of the assessment roll the city council shall provide for the payment out of the city treasury of onehalf of the cost of the proposed improvement  lien a upon the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council the amount as shown in the assessment roll assessed against each piece or parcel of property shall constitute a lien thereon from the time of the ratification by the city council and the payment thereof may be enforced by the city in the same manner as is the payment of city taxes  provided that such assessment shall be entered in a book to be kept for that purpose by the city clerk to be entitled assessment liens stating the name of the owner the location of the property the amount of the assessment and the time of payment such lien shall continue from the date of the entry of the lien on such assessment lien book until the expiration of five years from the date when the final payment is due and payable unless sooner paid b it shall be the duty of the city clerk when full payment is made by the owners of the abutting property of the assessments provided for in this article to make entry of satisfaction on the assessment lien book and thereupon such lien shall be extinguished  terms of payment  interest a when the assessment roll has been ratified in the manner prescribed by section 3692 each owner of property so assessed may within 30 days after such ratification pay into the city treasury the full amount of the assessment or shall have the right to have such assessment divided into five equal payments the first installment thereof to be due 30 days after the date of the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council and the remaining installments to be due in equal amounts respectively in one two three and four years from the date of the first installment with interest on unpaid installments at the rate of six percent per annum payable annually from date until paid in full b where the permanent improvement of any of the streets in the city is of the type commonly known as surface treatment the property owner shall have the right to have such assessment divided into four equal payments the first installment of which shall be due and payable 30 days after the date of the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council and the remaining installments to be due in equal amounts one two and three years from the date of the first installment with interest on unpaid installments at the rate of six percent per annum payable annually from date until paid  application of payments all appropriations made by the city for permanent improvements under the authority of this article together with the amounts of such assessment as may be paid in cash by the owners of abutting property within the time provided for in this article for the payment of assessments in full shall be applied to the payment of the contractor or other person making the improvements under contract with the city on monthly estimates to be approved by the city council  assessment certificates a for assessments made in compliance with this article remaining unpaid at the expiration of the time limit for the payment of assessments in full investigating all matters relating to the assessment and listing of property for taxation or for the relief of taxpayers and it shall be the duty of the city council to see that no property in the city escapes proper assessment and taxation in case it shall be discovered by the city council that there is real or personal property within the city which has not been returned assessed or listed for taxation or is listed on the county auditors books as being outside of the city or is improperly assessed or is listed in the name of the wrong person or is a double entry or is listed as being in the city or in case any other irregularity appears or exists it shall be the duty of the city council to forthwith report or cause to be reported the error or irregularity to the county auditor or other county or state officials to the end that no property properly liable for city taxes shall escape taxation by the city or its proper assessment or listing or shall be improperly taxed  annual levy the city council shall impose by ordinance an annual tax at such rate in its discretion as will yield an amount necessary for the general purposes of the city not exceeding the limit permitted by law such tax shall be levied by the city council on the property within the corporate limits as assessed for taxation for county and state purposes as provided in this chapter such tax rate shall remain the same from year to year unless changed by ordinance  use of proceeds of annual levy the proceeds of the annual property tax levy together with other income of the city shall be used for general municipal purposes to pay all current indebtedness and to pay the principal and interest on outstanding bonds or coupons of the city which may become due and payable during the fiscal year treasurer a complete account of all moneys collected during the preceding day and shall at that time turn over all such moneys to the treasurer  special real property tax assessments for rehabilitated historic properties a special tax assessment is created for eligible rehabilitated historic properties for ten years equal to the appraised value of the property at the time of preliminary certification where there is a conflict between provisions of this section and the enabling state code the more restrictive provision shall control 1 purpose it is the purpose of this section to a encourage the restoration of historic properties  b promote community development and redevelopment  c encourage sound community planning  and d promote the general health safety and welfare of the community 2 eligible properties a certification in order to be eligible for the special tax assessment historic properties must receive preliminary and final certification 1 to receive preliminary certification a property must meet the following conditions i the property has received historic designation ii the proposed rehabilitation work receives approval from the design review board drb iii be a project that commenced by or after  to the date of the adoption of this section and work was permitted to have begun prior to receiving preliminary certification  or iv be a project that commences on or after the date of the adoption of this section preliminary certification must be received prior to beginning work 2 to receive final certification a property must have met the following conditions i the property has received preliminary certification ii the minimum expenditures for rehabilitation were incurred and paid iii the completed rehabilitation receives approval from the drb as being consistent with the plans approved by drb as part of preliminary certification b historic designation as used in this section historic designation means the property maintains one or more of the following 1 the property is listed on the national register of historic places either individually or as a contributing property in a district 2 the property is at least 50 years old and is an individual landmark or a contributing property in a local district as designated by city council and listed as so designated in the city 3 eligible rehabilitation a standards for rehabilitation work to be eligible for the special tax assessment historic rehabilitations must be appropriate for the historic building and the historic district in which it is located this is achieved to the following standards 1 the historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved  the removal of historic materials or alterations of features that characterize each property shall be avoided 2 each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time place and use  changes that create a false sense of historical development shall not be undertaken 3 most properties change over time  those changes that have acquired historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved 4 distinctive features finishes and construction techniques or examples of craftsmanship that characterize a property should be preserved 5 deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced  where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature the new should match the old in design color texture and other visual qualities and where possible materials  replacement of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary physical or pictorial evidence 6 chemical or physical treatments such as sandblasting that cause damage to historic materials shall not be used  the surface cleaning of structures if appropriate shall be undertaken using the gentlest means possible 7 new additions exterior alterations or related new construction shall not destroy historic materials that characterize the property  the new work shall be differentiated from the old and shall be compatible with the massing size scale and architectural features to protect the historic integrity of the historic property and its environment 8 new additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be undertaken in such a manner that if removed in the future the essential form and integrity of the historic property and its environment would be unimpaired b work to be reviewed for preliminary and final certification the following work will be reviewed according to the standards set forth above 1 repairs to the exterior of the designated building 2 alterations to the exterior of the designated building 3 new construction on the property on which the building is located 4 any remaining work including interior work where the expenditures for such work are being used to satisfy the minimum expenditures for rehabilitation c minimum expenditures for rehabilitation means the owner or the owners estate rehabilitates the building with expenditures for rehabilitation exceeding 20 percent of the fair market value of the building fair market value means the appraised value as certified to the drb by a real estate appraiser licensed by the state the sales price as delineated in a bona fide contract of sale within 12 months of the time it is submitted or the most recent appraised value published by the county tax assessor d expenditures for rehabilitation means the actual cost of rehabilitation relating to one or more of the following 1 improvements located on or within the historic building as designated 2 improvements outside of but directly attached to the historic building which make possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions and features of the buildings that are significant to its historic architectural and cultural values costs associated with new structures or the addition of rentablehabitable floor space not attributed to efficient contemporary use of space within an existing historic structure shall not be included in the calculation of eligible costs 3 architectural and engineering services attributable to the design of the improvements 4 costs necessary to maintain the historic character or integrity of the building e scope the special tax assessment may apply to the following 1 structures rehabilitated 2 real property on which the building is located f time limits to be eligible for the special tax assessment rehabilitation must be completed within two years of the preliminary certification date if the project is not complete after two years but the minimum expenditures for rehabilitation have been incurred the property continues to receive the special assessment until the project is completed or until the end of the special assessment period whichever shall first occur 4 process a fee required there is a fee of $15000 required for final certification for each application for review of rehabilitation work of singlefamily andor duplex structures and $30000 for all other structures fees are payable to the city and final certification will not be given without payment of this fee b plan required owners of property seeking to receive the special tax assessment must submit an application provided by the planning department with all supporting documentation and application fee in order to be considered for preliminary certification this should be submitted before work is begun however work completed within the preceding 12 months may be considered at the discretion of the board c preliminary certification upon receipt of the completed application the proposal shall be placed on the next available agenda of the drb to determine if the project is consistent with the standards for rehabilitation in subsection 3883a above after the drb makes its determination the owner shall be notified in writing upon receipt of this determination the owner may 1 if the application is approved begin rehabilitation  2 if the application is not approved he may revise such application in accordance with comments provided by the drb  d substantive changes once preliminary certification is granted to an application substantive changes must be approved by the drb unapproved substantive changes are conducted at the risk of the property owner and may disqualify the project from eligibility additional expenditures will not qualify the project for an extension on the special assessment e final certification upon completion of the project the project must receive final certification in order to be eligible for the special assessment the drb will inspect completed projects to determine if the work is consistent with the approval granted by the drb pursuant to section 388 final certification will be granted when the completed work meets the standards and verification is made that expenditures have been made in accordance with subsection 3883c and d above upon receiving final certification the property will be assessed for the remainder of the special assessment period on the fair market value of the property at the time the preliminary certification was made or the final certification was made whichever occurred earlier f additional work below shall apply to all properties receiving final certification after date of city council adoption properties receiving final certification before this date shall be subject to subsection 2 below 1 all additional work on the exterior of the property shall be subject to design review via the established certificate of appropriateness process and approval matrix furthermore at the time of final certification the design review board may establish a preservation zone to identify critical architectural and historically significant elements that should be preserved this preservation zone may include interior rooms and elements as well as exterior elements that would not otherwise be subject to design review certificate of appropriateness process for the remainder of the special assessment period after final certification any additional work repair replacement modification to the preservation zone elements identified shall be subject to review by the design review board certificate of appropriateness process to ensure that all work is consistent with relevant design and preservation guidelines as adopted per section j of the zoning ordinance and the standards for rehabilitation work provided in this section if the additional work is found to be inconsistent with these guidelines the property owner may withdraw his request and cancel or revise the proposed additional work the design review board may designate review and approval authority to the planning director and design review board chair 2 current owners of participating properties receiving final certification before  shall upon adoption of this ordinance by city council be given by staff the following implementation options applicable for the remainder of their assessment period i for the remainder of the special assessment period after final certification the property owner shall notify the drb of any additional work other than ordinary maintenance the drb will review the work at a regularly scheduled hearing and determine whether the overall project is consistent with the standards for rehabilitation if the additional work is found to be inconsistent the property owner may withdraw his request and cancel or revise the proposed additional work ii participating properties shall be subject to the policy established in subsection 1 after a site visit and hearing by the board to establish a preservation zone for the property g decertification when the property has received final certification and has been assessed as rehabilitated historic property it remains so certified and must be granted the special assessment until the property becomes disqualified by any one of the following 1 written notice from the owner to the drb and the auditor requesting removal of the preferential assessment  2 removal of the historic designation by the city council  or 3 rescission of the approval of rehabilitation by the drb because of alterations or renovation by the owner or the owners estate which causes the property to no longer possess the qualities and features which made it eligible for final certification notification of any change affecting eligibility must be given immediately to the county assessor auditor and treasurer under no circumstances shall the sale or transfer of ownership of real property certified and assessed in accordance with this section and any ordinance in effect at the time disqualify the property from receiving the special property tax assessment under this section this provision shall be applicable and given full force and effect to any special property tax assessment granted prior to the effective date of this paragraph notwithstanding any ordinance in effect from time to time to the contrary h notification the city shall upon final certification of a property notify the county assessor auditor and treasurer that such property has been duly certified and is eligible for the special tax assessment i date effective if an application for preliminary or final certification is filed by may 1 or the preliminary or final certification is approved by august 1 the special assessment authorized herein is effective for that year otherwise it is effective beginning with the following year the special assessment only begins in the current or future tax years as provided for in this section in no instance may the special assessment be applied retroactively j application once the drb has granted the special property tax assessments authorized herein the owner of the property shall make application to the county auditor and other appropriate county offices at the directive of county officials for the special assessment provided this section and the provisions of those state laws the latter provisions shall control  local accommodations tax a authority this tax is enacted pursuant to the sc as amended  6150061570 which provides in part that a local governing body may impose by ordinance a local accommodations tax not to exceed three percent b purpose and intent this local accommodations tax is enacted to preserve the general health safety and welfare of the general public within the city and to specifically improve and increase tourismrelated activities and facilities and to enhance the quality of life in the city for its citizens and its visitors the revenue generated by the local accommodations tax must be used exclusively for the following purposes 1 tourismrelated buildings including but not limited to civic centers coliseums and aquariums  2 cultural recreational or historic facilities  3 highways roads streets and bridges providing access to tourist destinations  4 advertisements and promotions related to tourism development  or 5 water and sewer infrastructure to serve tourismrelated demand c imposition of local accommodations tax a uniform tax equal to three percent is hereby imposed on the gross proceeds derived from the rental or charges for accommodations furnished to transients as provided in sc a and is imposed on every person engaged in the business of furnishing accommodations to transients for consideration within the city included are gross proceeds derived from the rental or charges for any rooms campground spaces lodgings or sleeping accommodations furnished to transients by any hotel inn tourist court tourist camp motel campground residence or any place in which rooms lodgings or sleeping accommodations are furnished to transients for a consideration this tax does not apply where the facilities consist of less than six sleeping rooms contained on the same premises which is used as the individuals place of abode the gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of sleeping accommodations supplied by the same person for a period of ninety continuous days are not considered proceeds from transients this tax does not apply to additional guest charges as defined in sc b as amended d accounting for local accommodations tax all proceeds derived from the local accommodations tax must be kept in a separate fund segregated from the city general fund this fund shall be known as the capital development fund all interest generated by the local accommodations tax fund must be credited to the capital development fund e payment of local accommodations tax payment of the local accommodations tax shall be the responsibility of the consumer of the services described in subsection c this tax shall be paid at the time of the delivery of the services or items to which the tax applies and shall be collected by the provider or seller of the services or items f remittance to the city the taxes collected by the seller or provider of the services or items as required in subsection e shall be remitted to the city business license administrator as set forth herein along with such return or form as may be established by the business license administrator for such purpose when the estimated amount of average tax is more than $5000 per month that seller or provider shall remit the amount due on a monthly basis when the estimated amount of average tax is $2500 to $5000 per month that seller or provider shall remit on a quarterly basis when the estimated amount is less than $2500 per month that seller or provider shall remit on an annual basis g payment due dates taxes and required reports shall be submitted to the business license administrator by the 20 th day of the month following the due date of the tax payment and shall cover sales of the previous month quarter andor year depending on the sellers monthly average tax any taxes not timely remitted shall be subject to a penalty of five percent of the unpaid tax for each month or portion thereof after the due date until paid the failure to collect from patrons the tax imposed by this section shall not relieve any establishment subject to this section from making the required remittance h penalties for violations any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be subject to punishment under section 113 of this conviction each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of liability for delinquent taxes penalties and costs provided for herein i open date and less than 105 days late shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent for late payment  and taxes paid more than 105 days from the date of the tax book open date will be subject to a meaning is intended agency means the city manager auxiliary services means any communications service in addition to regular subscriber services including but not limited to services for which a perprogram or perchannel charge is made pay tv burglar alarm services data or other electronic transmission services facsimile reproduction services meter reading services interactive twoway services and any other service utilizing any facility or equipment of a cable communications system operating pursuant to a franchise under this chapter cable communications system cable system cable television system or catv system mean any facility that in whole or in part receives directly or indirectly over the air and amplifies or otherwise modifies the signals of television or radio stations and distributes such signals by wire or cable to subscribing members of the public who pay for such services this also includes any such systems auxiliary services however this does not include any portion of any system the primary business of which is to provide telephonic telegraphic or similar services except that such system shall be considered a cable system to the extent that such faculty is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers channel means a band of frequencies six megahertz wide in the electromagnetic spectrum capable of carrying either one audio visual television signal and few nonvideo signals or a large number of nonvideo signals federal communications commission or fcc mean the present federal agency of that name as constituted by the communications act of 193 or any successor agency created by federal laws franchise means a nonexclusive authorization granted by the franchise authority which permits the construction operation and maintenance of a cable communications system within the franchise area pursuant to this chapter franchise area means that portion of the franchise entity for which a franchise is granted under the authority of this chapter the franchise area may or may not be coterminous with the franchise entity franchise authority means the city council franchise entity means all areas within the corporate limits of the city including any area henceforth added thereto during the terms of any franchise granted hereunder or the city a municipal corporation and political subdivision of the state whichever is applicable to the context in which the term is used grantee means a holder of a franchise issued by the franchise entity pursuant to this chapter gross revenues means all cash credits compensation property of any kind or nature or other consideration directly or indirectly received by a grantee its affiliates subsidiaries parents and any other person or entity in which the grantee has a financial interest or which has a financial interest in the grantee including but not limited to 1 revenue from all charges for regular subscriber services premium services auxiliary services or other cable services provided to subscribers in the franchise area including leased access fees less refunds but including the full amount recovered by any collection agency  2 revenue from all charges for programming or the insertion of commercial advertisements upon a cable television system in the franchise area  3 revenue from all charges for the leased use of studios or equipment  4 revenue from all charges for the sale installation connection and reinstatement of equipment and services for utilization of the cable communications system and the provision of subscriber and other services in remuneration in nonmonetary form values at retail price levels received by a grantee in consideration for performance by grantee of any advertising programming or other service in connection with the cable television system  7 revenues from any television programming or any other services offered in the franchise area by any means of delivery whatsoever where such programming or services are provided by means of the system or any part thereof  and 8 revenues from all cable services cable operations and cablerelated activities within the city including any and all ancillary and nonsubscriber services operations or activities related to the cable system the phrase financial interest as used in this definition shall include but not be limited to the following to the extent derived from the operation of the cable system 1 any contract in which a grantee or any named owner thereof is to receive a percentage of the gross revenues andor a percentage of the net or other income of the other party to the transaction by reason of the activities encompassed by such contract  2 any debt relationship in which a grantee or any named owner thereof as debtor borrows funds at a rate more advantageous than that generally available to similarly situated entities of similar credit worthiness  3 any debt relationship in which a grantee or any named owner thereof as creditor receives a rate of interest exceeding that which would otherwise be paid by a similarly situated debtor of similar credit worthiness  or 4 any debt relationship which has conversion privileges to a origination programming it does not include specialized programming for which a perprogram or perchannel charge is made street means the surface of and space above and below any public street avenue or located in the franchise entity subscriber means any person receiving regular subscriber service usable activated channels means channels engineered at the headend of the cable television system for the provision of services generally available to subscribers of the cable television system regardless of whether services actually are provided including any channel designated for public definitions generally  12 franchise to operate necessary a it shall be unlawful to commence or engage in the construction operation or maintenance of a cable communications system without a franchise issued under this chapter the franchise authority may by ordinance award a franchise to construct operate and maintain a cable communications system within all or any portion of the franchise entity to any person whether operating under an existing franchise or not who makes application for authority to furnish a cable communications system which complies with the terms and conditions of this chapter and applicable laws regulations and ordinances provided that no franchise shall be awarded to an applicant if the proposed franchise service area is drawn in such a way as to deny access to cable service to any group of potential residential cable subscribers because of the income of the residents of the local area in which such group resides provided further that this section and chapter shall not be deemed to require the grant of a franchise to any particular person or to prohibit the franchise authority from restricting the number of grantees should it determine such action or restriction would be in the public interest b it shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this section and upon conviction therefor any such person shall be punished as provided by section 113 each day that any such violation continues or is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense 54 term of franchise  revocation a any franchise granted by the franchise authority shall be for a term of up to seven years following the date such franchise is accepted by the grantee and upon application of the grantee and review of the performance of the grantee in a public proceeding undertaken pursuant to the provisions of section 4023 the franchise authority may renew the franchise for successive sevenyear periods with such modification of terms as the franchise authority may determine to be necessary to meet the present and future needs and interests of the franchise entity and its citizens provided however that the franchise authority may grant franchises or franchise renewals exceeding seven years but not exceeding 15 years pursuant to the provisions of section 4030 b the franchise authority may revoke any franchise granted under this chapter in the event the grantee shall refuse or neglect to comply with any material requirement or limitation contained in this chapter or applicable laws regulations or ordinances c should the franchise authority or agency determine that the grantee of a franchise issued under this chapter is in violation of any requirement or limitation of either this chapter or the franchise issued thereunder it shall so notify the grantee and the grantee shall within 30 days bring the franchise system into compliance reporting any corrective action taken to the franchise authority in writing d if the franchise authority or agency finds that compliance has not been achieved within 30 days of the notice of violation and that no substantial good faith progress is being made toward compliance it may schedule a public hearing to determine whether the franchise should be revoked the grantee and the public shall be given at least 30 days notice of such a hearing and all interested persons shall be heard in open hearing e at the conclusion of the public hearing the franchise authority shall determine whether the franchise should be revoked and shall put forth in writing the facts and reasons upon which its decision is based 55 cable television system agency the franchise authority hereby designates and empowers the city manager or his designee to act for it in administrative
